isis.stitle: HENDRICKSON AIR SUSPENSION WITH TRAILING LEAF SPRINGS - HENDRICKSON AIR SUSPENSION COMPONENTS - HEIGHT CONTROL VALVE

svcprocinfo.para: The height control valve ( Figure 3) is the brain of the air suspension and is sensitive to height. When properly adjusted, it will provide and maintain proper ride height.

svcsubproc.title: Height Control Valve Adjustment
svcsubproc.para: On Hendrickson air suspension the spring height is measured between the center line of the shock absorber upper and lower mounting bolts ( Figure 4). If resetting the air spring (bag) to obtain the proper ride height, deflate the system and reset the height by inflating the air spring (bag). Adjust the control valve extension leveling rod accordingly to obtain the proper specification as shown in ( Figure 4).

svcsubproc.title: Height Control Valve Check ( Figure 3and Figure 4)
svcsubproc.para: To check the height control valve to see if it is operating properly, have the vehicle air pressure at a minimum of 100 psi (689 kpa).

step1.para: Disconnect leveling valve arm extension rod from height control valve arm.

Raise height control valve arm approximately 45 degrees above horizontal. Air pressure at the air springs should begin to increase within 10 seconds. This action will cause the vehicle frame to rise. This can easily be detected by feeling or watching the shock absorber dust tube rise also.

Lower height control valve arm approximately 45 degrees below horizontal. Air pressure at the air spring should begin to decrease. Let air escape until the ride height (as measured in Figure 4) is about 19 inches (483mm).
Raise valve lever to 45 degrees above horizontal again, until air spring height is at proper specification as shown in Figure 4.
Connect arm extension rod to control valve arm.
After 15 minutes, recheck ride height dimension. If not the same (as shown in Figure 4), readjust height control arm.
